column7: Comment Text

Dear Chairman Pai 

Thank you for your efforts to repeal the federal government’s Title II internet regulations. I support removing these regulations so that the internet is once again free and open. Repealing Title II will increase broadband deployment and competition, and expand consumer choice. There are too many restrictions in the world and more freedoms help settle peoples fears of things they don't understand. 


sincerely yours,

The FCC Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me. I urge you to protect them.

I don't want ISPs to have the power to block websites, slow them down, make some more accessible than others, or split the Internet into "fast lanes" for companies that pay and "slow lanes" for the rest.

Now is not the time to let giant ISPs censor what we see and do online.

Censorship by ISPs is a serious problem. Comcast has throttled Netflix, AT&T blocked FaceTime, Time Warner Cable throttled the popular game League of Legends, and Verizon admitted it will introduce fast lanes for sites that pay—and slow lanes for everyone else—if the FCC lifts the rules. This hurts consumers and businesses large and small.

Courts have made clear that if the FCC ends Title II classification, the FCC must let ISPs offer fast lanes to websites for a fee, and Chairman Pai has made clear that he intends to do just this.

But if you let ISPs make some websites fast and others artificially slow—for a fee—you will kill the open marketplace that has enabled millions of small businesses and created the 5 most valuable companies in America—just to further enrich a few much less valuable cable giants famous for sky-high prices and abysmal customer service.

I'm sending this to the FCC's open proceeding, but I worry that Chairman Pai, a former Verizon lawyer, has made his plans and will ignore me and millions of other Americans.

So I'm also sending this to my members of Congress. Please publicly support Title II rules and denounce Chairman Pai's plans. Do whatever you can to dissuade him.

Thank you!
Joey

I'm concerned about net neutrality. I believe Congress should hear from the experts on net neutrality and pass a law that places enforceable rules on broadband providers that prevents them or any other company from controlling the market. It may be the right decision to reverse the classification of the companies as a utility so they can continue forward like any other competitive company. That is probably the right thing to do (I'm no expert). I understand that, particularly as conservatives, you would want to limit the amount of government regulation in the market and in our lives. However, I don't think the Telecom companies are simply to be trusted. Congress needs to pass a law with bipartisan support instead of relying on FCC rules that are subject to changing administrations.

Jeanne Schlatter

Please keep the Open Internet rules. I'm wary of government regulation in general, but this is a classic example of a place where government regulation opens up competition and results in better products/services for everybody.

It surprised me when this issue first came up and I learned that ISPs aren't required to treat traffic equally like phone companies, shipping companies, and others are. It seems so logical that these things all belong in the same category, because none of them should be favoring some content (virtual or physical).

Free and open source software is important to me, and charging even small amounts is often a huge barrier to these kinds of projects. Making it harder to get fast Internet connections to end users for open, decentralized projects is not a good idea.

The result of letting ISPs charge content providers for faster speeds is obvious: it will become a lot harder for new innovators to compete, and harder for organizations to offer useful services for free.

Letting ISPs choose what end users do and see online is a terrible idea. Charging for bandwidth for certain sites will do that, and it will allow the ISPs to abuse their monopoly position in many markets to the detriment of end users.

Censorship by ISPs is a serious problem. Comcast has throttled Netflix, AT&T blocked FaceTime, Time Warner Cable throttled the popular game League of Legends, and Verizon admitted it will introduce fast lanes for sites that pay—and slow lanes for everyone else—if the FCC lifts the rules. This hurts consumers and businesses large and small.

Courts have made clear that if the FCC ends Title II classification, the FCC must let ISPs offer fast lanes to websites for a fee, and Chairman Pai has made clear that he intends to do just this.

But if you let ISPs make some websites fast and others artificially slow—for a fee—you will kill the open marketplace that has enabled millions of small businesses and created the 5 most valuable companies in America—just to further enrich a few much less valuable cable giants famous for sky-high prices and abysmal customer service.

I'm sending this to the FCC's open proceeding, but I worry that Chairman Pai, a former Verizon lawyer, has made his plans and will ignore me and millions of other Americans.

So I'm also sending this to my members of Congress. Please publicly support Title II rules and denounce Chairman Pai's plans. Do whatever you can to dissuade him.

Thank you!
Brian

Courts have made clear that if the FCC ends Title II classification, the FCC must let ISPs offer fast lanes to websites for a fee, and Chairman Pai has made clear that he intends to do just this.

But if you let ISPs make some websites fast and others artificially slow—for a fee—you will kill the open marketplace that has enabled millions of small businesses and created the 5 most valuable companies in America—just to further enrich a few much less valuable cable giants famous for sky-high prices and abysmal customer service.

I'm sending this to the FCC's open proceeding, but I worry that Chairman Pai, a former Verizon lawyer, has made his plans and will ignore me and millions of other Americans.

So I'm also sending this to my members of Congress. Please publicly support Title II rules and denounce Chairman Pai's plans. Do whatever you can to dissuade him.

Thank you!
Eric

I've heard your argument: that freedom from regulation brings lower prices. Internet access is vital to my, and almost every other American's everyday lives. It's a utility, so treat it like one and regulate it for the good of all America, not just the privileged few who profit from this kind of blatant exploitation.

Thank you!

Comcast has throttled Netflix, AT&T blocked FaceTime, Time Warner Cable throttled the popular game League of Legends, and Verizon admitted it will introduce fast lanes for sites that pay—and slow lanes for everyone else—if the FCC lifts the rules. This hurts consumers and businesses large and small.

Courts have made clear that if the FCC ends Title II classification, the FCC must let ISPs offer fast lanes to websites for a fee, and Chairman Pai has made clear that he intends to do just this.

But if you let ISPs make some websites fast and others artificially slow—for a fee—you will kill the open marketplace that has enabled millions of small businesses and created the 5 most valuable companies in America—just to further enrich a few much less valuable cable giants famous for sky-high prices and abysmal customer service.

I'm sending this to the FCC's open proceeding, but I worry that Chairman Pai, a former Verizon lawyer, has made his plans and will ignore me and millions of other Americans.

So I'm also sending this to my members of Congress. Please publicly support Title II rules and denounce Chairman Pai's plans. Do whatever you can to dissuade him.

Thank you!
Zach

I am commenting to state that I am against any efforts to weaken net neutrality. I feel as long as ISPs maintain monopolies or near monopolies over their distribution areas we need strong government regulation to protect the consumers and companies that do business on the web. We already have open investigations where ISPs are throttling businesses to force them into a fast lane (such as Verizon and Netflix) and so while it is an assumption who is to say the ISPs won't be more heavy handed once this actually becomes legal. Finally the only actions I've ever seen the ISPs make to improve their service was when Google was thinking about moving into my region. I do not believe there will be any increase in infrastructure unless there is a direct competitor with a sizeable amount of capital to back them up (unlike most smaller competitor who would likely be just bought out by the big ISPs).

Thank you!

Paragraph 82 asks for input on whether throttling should be regulated. In the past ISPs have throttled content based on their own determination of what was lawful or permissible, and had to be forced to stop in the courts. Isn’t it possible they could do this again? I’m also concerned by mobile providers who say a plan is “unlimited,” but when you exceed the data cap, only throttle sites and services that aren’t part of their approved zero-rating network. \n\nI’m worried that the protections that are in place will be weakened if we change the way they’re enforced. I would support a new regulation style if it guarantees the same or better protections, but not if we lose any. Thanks for reading my comment.

But if you let ISPs make some websites fast and others artificially slow—for a fee—you will kill the open marketplace that has enabled millions of small businesses and created the 5 most valuable companies in America—just to further enrich a few much less valuable cable giants famous for sky-high prices and abysmal customer service.

I'm sending this to the FCC's open proceeding, but I worry that Chairman Pai, a former Verizon lawyer, has made his plans and will ignore me and millions of other Americans.

So I'm also sending this to my members of Congress. Please publicly support Title II rules and denounce Chairman Pai's plans. Do whatever you can to dissuade him.

Thank you!
Kyle Garcia

The FCC Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me. I urge you to protect them.

I don't want ISPs to have the power to block websites, slow them down, make some more accessible than others, or split the Internet into "fast lanes" for companies that pay and "slow lanes" for the rest.

Now is not the time to let giant ISPs censor what we see and do online.

Censorship by ISPs is a serious problem. Comcast has throttled Netflix, AT&T blocked FaceTime, Time Warner Cable throttled the popular game League of Legends, and Verizon admitted it will introduce fast lanes for sites that pay—and slow lanes for everyone else—if the FCC lifts the rules. I am against reversing net neutrality rules and putting Internet Service Providers (ISPs) in charge of the internet. ISPs will operate in their own interests and not in the interests of what is best for the American public, our democracy and our economy. Broadband companies have been guilty of: * deliberately throttling internet traffic * squeezing customers with arbitrary data caps * misleading consumers about the meaning of “unlimited” internet * giving privileged treatment to companies they own * strong-arming cities to prevent them from giving their residents high-speed internet * avoiding real competition at all costs Consumers, small businesses, and all Americans deserve an open internet. So to restate my position: I am against the chairman's plan to reverse the net neutrality rules. I believe doing so will destroy a vital engine for innovation, growth, and communication.

The FCC Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me. I urge you to protect them.

I don't want ISPs to have the power to block websites, slow them down, make some more accessible than others, or split the Internet into "fast lanes" for companies that pay and "slow lanes" for the rest.

Now is not the time to let giant ISPs censor what we see and do online.

Censorship by ISPs is a serious problem. Comcast has throttled Netflix, AT&T blocked FaceTime, Time Warner Cable throttled the popular game League of Legends, and Verizon admitted it will introduce fast lanes for sites that pay—and slow lanes for everyone else—if the FCC lifts the rules. This hurts consumers and businesses large and small.

Courts have made clear that if the FCC ends Title II classification, the FCC must let ISPs offer fast lanes to websites for a fee, and Chairman Pai has made clear that he intends to do just this.

But if you let ISPs make some websites fast and others artificially slow—for a fee—you will kill the open marketplace that has enabled millions of small businesses and created the 5 most valuable companies in America—just to further enrich a few much less valuable cable giants famous for sky-high prices and abysmal customer service.

I'm sending this to the FCC's open proceeding, but I worry that Chairman Pai, a former Verizon lawyer, has made his plans and will ignore me and millions of other Americans.

So I'm also sending this to my members of Congress. Please publicly support Title II rules and denounce Chairman Pai's plans. Do whatever you can to dissuade him.

Thank you!

FCC Chairman Ajit Pai recently claimed that treating the internet as a utility stifles growth. This kind of thinking is akin to thinking that advances were lost because the water utility company couldn't charge us more for using a gallon of water to make tea than they do for a using gallon to make kool-aid. There should be a framework to rectify data freedoms such as data caps. The internet needs regulation because ISPs have a proven track record of price gouging, and stifling growth in bandwidth expansion.

Dear FCC,

It's despicable to see that you do not care about net neutrality. Ajit Pai is one of the worst things to happen to the FCC. 
There's something called the Golden Rule: Do unto others as you want them to do unto you. I'm certain you don't want your privacy sold around, so don't do it to the people. That's colluded and very fishy. This makes me skeptical of the FCC's intentions and concerned about our rights being infringed.

Please heed this call to stop even more surveillance in its tracks before it gets any worse.
Thanks.

Samuel S.

I understand that NPRM is focused on re-reclassifying broadband under Title I and that they are seeking to revise the law that presently the FCC is using to enforce it.

I am concerned that over the years the FCC has tried to enact strong rules regarding net neutrality using many other types of laws and that those laws have not been effective in providing that protection. 

I am only in favor of a new regulation style if it guarantees the same or better protections as those we already have, but not if they are less protective or ineffective in providing those protections.

Comcast has throttled Netflix, AT&T blocked FaceTime, Time Warner Cable throttled the popular game League of Legends, and Verizon admitted it will introduce fast lanes for sites that pay—and slow lanes for everyone else—if the FCC lifts the rules. This hurts consumers and businesses large and small.

Courts have made clear that if the FCC ends Title II classification, the FCC must let ISPs offer fast lanes to websites for a fee, and Chairman Pai has made clear that he intends to do just this.

But if you let ISPs make some websites fast and others artificially slow—for a fee—you will kill the open marketplace that has enabled millions of small businesses and created the 5 most valuable companies in America—just to further enrich a few much less valuable cable giants famous for sky-high prices and abysmal customer service.

I'm sending this to the FCC's open proceeding, but I worry that Chairman Pai, a former Verizon lawyer, has made his plans and will ignore me and millions of other Americans.

So I'm also sending this to my members of Congress. Please publicly support Title II rules and denounce Chairman Pai's plans. Do whatever you can to dissuade him.

Thank you!
Helen Syen

Nobody benefits from lost net neutrality. Nobody. Everyone, from the poorest worker to the richest CEO, benefits from net neutrality, because without it, hundreds of different websites all of us visit every day would have their connection ground to such a slow that they'd be rendered practically inaccessible.

The loss of net neutrality would be devastating, rendering many uses of one of humanity's greatest inventions useless, and destroying many, many jobs, friendships, and relationships.

Please protect net neutrality.

~Ramon

Dear FCC Commissioners and Chairman Ajit Pai,

I am writing on behalf of the generation of internet users who grew up on AOL, dial-up internet, and the musings of Robert Kahn and Vint Cerf. We demand the preservation of an open internet and for the preservation of the Title II classification of Internet Service Providers. Reclassifying these entities would destroy the consumer internet freedoms so costly won by the internet at large.  Please preserve these consumer protections and prevent ISPs from charging smaller websites and startups for preferential access to the web. Creating new arbitrary and damaging markets for ISPs would destroy the open internet and the internet itself as envisioned by its creators. Please rethink your plan of action and think of how negatively it would impact internet users at large- this would be a grave error and a slap in the face to all the content creators who have helped make the internet what it is today.

Sincerely,

Joseph Serafin

The FCC Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me. I urge you to protect them.

I don't want ISPs to have the power to block websites, slow them down, make some more accessible than others, or split the Internet into "fast lanes" for companies that pay and "slow lanes" for the rest.

Now is not the time to let giant ISPs censor what we see and do online.

Censorship by ISPs is a serious problem. Comcast has throttled Netflix, AT&T blocked FaceTime, Time Warner Cable throttled the popular game League of Legends, and Verizon admitted it will introduce fast lanes for sites that pay—and slow lanes for everyone else—if the FCC lifts the rules. This hurts consumers and businesses large and small.

Courts have made clear that if the FCC ends Title II classification, the FCC must let ISPs offer fast lanes to websites for a fee, and Chairman Pai has made clear that he intends to do just this.

But if you let ISPs make some websites fast and others artificially slow—for a fee—you will kill the open marketplace that has enabled millions of small businesses and created the 5 most valuable companies in America—just to further enrich a few much less valuable cable giants famous for sky-high prices and abysmal customer service.

I'm sending this to the FCC's open proceeding, but I worry that Chairman Pai, a former Verizon lawyer, has made his plans and will ignore me and millions of other Americans.

So I'm also sending this to my members of Congress. Please publicly support Title II rules and denounce Chairman Pai's plans. Do whatever you can to dissuade him.

Thank you!
Kathleen

But if you let ISPs make some websites fast and others artificially slow—for a fee—you will kill the open marketplace that has enabled millions of small businesses and created the 5 most valuable companies in America—just to further enrich a few much less valuable cable giants famous for sky-high prices and abysmal customer service.

I'm sending this to the FCC's open proceeding, but I worry that Chairman Pai, a former Verizon lawyer, has made his plans and will ignore me and millions of other Americans.

So I'm also sending this to my members of Congress. Please publicly support Title II rules and denounce Chairman Pai's plans. Do whatever you can to dissuade him.

Thank you!
Janet Crossen

The FCC Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me. I urge you to protect them.

I don't want ISPs to have the power to block websites, slow them down, make some more accessible than others, or split the Internet into "fast lanes" for companies that pay and "slow lanes" for the rest.

Dear FCC,

Please understand the importance of net neutrality. The internet connects everyone around the world. It is a place where all ideas and knowledge are shared. Everyone has equal right to access information on the internet without discrimination.of race, class, or gender. A neutral internet is a free, fair, and equal ground for all to enjoy.

Monopolies like the cable companies should have no right to impose their rules and regulations on the internet. Their creation of internet fast lanes and slow lanes benefits nothing other than themselves while robbing every hardworking citizen and many many enterprises that must use the internet to function with a needless fee. The monopolies reap all of the benefits of their own created system, while everyone else will be strained by it. 

The internet is an amazing and revolutionary invention that has elevated our existence. It shrinks the world and brings us closer as a species than anything else. Creating a divide of "rich" and "poor" on the internet violates all that the internet stands for. The creation of segregation on the internet is absolutely appalling and must never be done. The internet should be equal to all. Everyone deserves to surf the internet without any hindrance. Please preserve net neutrality.

I don't want ISPs to have the power to block websites, slow them down, make some more accessible than others, or split the Internet into "fast lanes" for companies that pay and "slow lanes" for the rest.

Now is not the time to let giant ISPs censor what we see and do online.

Censorship by ISPs is a serious problem. Comcast has throttled Netflix, AT&T blocked FaceTime, Time Warner Cable throttled the popular game League of Legends, and Verizon admitted it will introduce fast lanes for sites that pay—and slow lanes for everyone else—if the FCC lifts the rules. This hurts consumers and businesses large and small.

Courts have made clear that if the FCC ends Title II classification, the FCC must let ISPs offer fast lanes to websites for a fee, and Chairman Pai has made clear that he intends to do just this.

But if you let ISPs make some websites fast and others artificially slow—for a fee—you will kill the open marketplace that has enabled millions of small businesses and created the 5 most valuable companies in America—just to further enrich a few much less valuable cable giants famous for sky-high prices and abysmal customer service.

I'm sending this to the FCC's open proceeding, but I worry that Chairman Pai, a former Verizon lawyer, has made his plans and will ignore me and millions of other Americans.

So I'm also sending this to my members of Congress. Please publicly support Title II rules and denounce Chairman Pai's plans. Do whatever you can to dissuade him.

Thank you!
Andrew Hernandez

i moved to this add JULY 2014, i transferred my Comcast/Infinity ( Internet/TV) to my new add.
in this add they only had very basic TV/ Internet connections. 
when we requested to move our bundle Comcast told us that they will transfer to this add.
comcast didn't have new wiring etc for this add. they said it will be done in 30 days.. 
Anyway , long story short i have been dealing with them since i moved to this add. most of the time my internet dont work, some time my dont work.. i call them , they send signal, they send their technicians, their survey companies, outside hired contractors, i mst have seen 100's of comcast tech/ hired outside contractors in my property finding gasline, electric line, putting flags all over, paint all over etc...
couple of months ago finally they put some connection box in my property, so i thought everything is going to be fine.
after that also my problem still the same.. i called them many times , they kept telling me oh in your area services are down it will be back soon.. then next day then next week etc...
today they send a technician and we spend hours together to find out what h=is the root cause. so we noticed that the Box they installed in my property is not connected to main cable from the main pole, and he says he doesn't have right tool to connect, he is a residential technical support, for this they need to send mechanical tech. and he told me that my internet wire and tv cable is old and bad so he replaced those.
MAIN PROBLEM STILL NOT RESOLVED, THE CABLE WHICH IS CONNECTED TO MY HOUSE IS NOT BERRIED AND GOING ALL OVER THE PROPERTY ( ALMOST 200 FEET) , AND IT IS CONNECTED WITH SOME OTHER BOX WHICH LOSSES THE SIGNAL ALL THE TIME. I HAVE 200 FEET NOT BERRIED CABLE ALL OVER THE PROPERTY , WE HAVE DOGS, HORSES AND HUMANS ROAMING FREELY  IN THE PROPERTY AND IT IS NOT SAFE+ I LOOSE CONNECTION + WEAK SIGNALS...
I AM REALLY FED UP AND TIRED OF CALLING THEM, TRYING TO RESOLVE AND FIX...
THEY HAVE BEEN CHARGING ME FULL PREMIUM FOR SUCH A INFERIOR SERVICE, SO MUCH INCONVENIENCE, SO MANY ISSUES, FLAGS, PAINT ALL OVER THE PROPERTY.
I REALLY WANT THE PROPER SERVICE WHAT I AM PAYING THEM FOR SINCE JULY 2014.
THANKS FOR LISTENING.

This will help make our Country a leader in broadband services and broadband use.

The FCC Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me. I urge you to protect them.

I don't want ISPs to have the power to block websites, slow them down, make some more accessible than others, or split the Internet into "fast lanes" for companies that pay and "slow lanes" for the rest.

Now is not the time to let giant ISPs censor what we see and do online.

Censorship by ISPs is a serious problem. Comcast has throttled Netflix, AT&T blocked FaceTime, Time Warner Cable throttled the popular game League of Legends, and Verizon admitted it will introduce fast lanes for sites that pay—and slow lanes for everyone else—if the FCC lifts the rules. This hurts consumers and businesses large and small.

Courts have made clear that if the FCC ends Title II classification, the FCC must let ISPs offer fast lanes to websites for a fee, and Chairman Pai has made clear that he intends to do just this.

But if you let ISPs make some websites fast and others artificially slow—for a fee—you will kill the open marketplace that has enabled millions of small businesses and created the 5 most valuable companies in America—just to further enrich a few much less valuable cable giants famous for sky-high prices and abysmal customer service.

I'm sending this to the FCC's open proceeding, but I worry that Chairman Pai, a former Verizon lawyer, has made his plans and will ignore me and millions of other Americans.

So I'm also sending this to my members of Congress. Please publicly support Title II rules and denounce Chairman Pai's plans. Do whatever you can to dissuade him.

Thank you!
Charlotte Sines

The FCC should continue to regulate Internet Service Providers and require that all content is treated equally.  ISP's should not be allowed to restrict or slow content based on the source, destination or subject matter.  There is not enough competition among Internet Service Providers to give consumers a real choice of other providers.  Most consumers have only one or two providers available due to the ownership of the local loop.\n\nIf the FCC truly wishes to improve competition, it should require that the owners of the local circuit allow the circuit to be used by any ISP chosen by the consumer.  Monopolies are unfairly controlling access to the local circuit by buying up all the local circuits in large geographic areas.  Consumers cannot find enough ISPs in their geographic area to provide any real competition.  Control of the local circuit should be fully returned to the consumer, not placed under further control by a single ISP.

I strongly oppose Sen. Lee's Restoring Internet Freedom Act. Too few companies own and control access to the internet; especially where I live. From what I've read on Mike Lee's page for Internet Freedom, this will allow Comcast to govern and police itself when it comes to internet connectivity. The Internet Freedom Act would be like if Wal-Mart had their own sovereignty within its doors alongside with a judge, jail, and electric chair; this is why we have local and state police, municipal and supreme justices. I understand that even though the FCC may be a bureaucratic extension of our government, the FCC should be well versed on communication technologies their constituents and themselves rely on. I understand the internet is an ever-changing beast that has lead us to great innovations, but we have to understand that the internet is no longer a luxury; it is a necessity. The moment when we the people are required to go online and apply for jobs, signup for healthcare, communicate with our insurance company, communicate with other people, do our jobs etc. is when the best interest of the internet became for the people. The FCC should be doing their job making sure nothing takes advantage of the people when connecting to the internet and not let major internet companies who are already in control decide what is acceptable for us without oversight.

Information has come to me that the FCC Chairman intends to reverse net neutrality rules and put big Internet Service Providers in charge of the internet. I am firmly against this action. I believe that these ISPs will operate solely in their own interests and not in the interests of what is best for the American public. In the past 10 years, broadband companies have been guilty of: deliberately throttling internet traffic, squeezing customers with arbitrary data caps, misleading consumers about the meaning of “unlimited” internet, giving privileged treatment to companies they own, strong-arming cities to prevent them from giving their residents high-speed internet, and avoiding real competition at all costs. Consumers, small businesses, and all Americans deserve an open internet. So to restate my position: I am against the chairman's plan to reverse the net neutrality rules. I believe doing so will destroy a vital engine for innovation, growth, communication and commerce.

Dear Chairman Pai, \n \nThank you for your efforts to repeal the federal government's Title II internet regulations. I support removing these regulations so that the internet is once again free and open. Repealing Title II will increase broadband deployment and competition, and expand consumer choice.

Thank you for your efforts to repeal the federal government's Title II internet regulations. I support removing these regulations so that the internet is once again free and open. Repealing Title II will increase broadband deployment and competition, and expand consumer choice.

The FCC Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me. 

1.  I urge you to keep rules that prevent telephone/Cable TV/giant ISP companies from receiving data of Internet users that control how much of what Internet users can and cannot access when.

2.  I don't want ISPs to have the power to block websites, slow them down, make some more accessible than others, or split the Internet into "fast lanes" for companies that pay and "slow lanes" for the rest.

Now is not the time to let giant ISPs censor what we see and do online.

3.  Censorship by ISPs is a serious problem. For example, Comcast has throttled Netflix; AT&T blocked FaceTime; Time Warner Cable throttled the popular game League of Legends; and Verizon admitted it will introduce fast lanes for sites that pay—and slow lanes for everyone else—if the FCC lifts the rules. This hurts consumers and businesses large and small.

Courts have made clear that if the FCC ends Title II classification, the FCC must let ISPs offer fast lanes to websites for a fee, and Chairman Pai has made clear that he intends to do just this.

But if you let ISPs make some websites fast and others artificially slow—for a fee—you will kill the open marketplace that has enabled millions of small businesses and created the 5 most valuable companies in America—just to further enrich a few much less valuable cable giants famous for sky-high prices and abysmal customer service.

I'm sending this to the FCC's open proceeding, but I worry and figure that Chairman Pai, a former Verizon lawyer, will ignore me and millions of other Americans who properly use and value the Internet as it is - free and accessable.

I am also sending this to my members of Congress. Please publicly support Title II rules and denounce Chairman Pai's plans. 

Do whatever you can to dissuade him and give him pause.  Every action has an equal and opposite reaction.  This a law of Physics.  No human is immune from its affect.

Thank you!
Carolynn Kohout

column6: Dr. Alton and the Rev. Mrs Norma Smith
column7:
The FCC Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me. I urge you to protect them.

I don't want ISPs to have the power to block websites, slow them down, make some more accessible than others, or split the Internet into "fast lanes" for companies that pay and "slow lanes" for the rest.

Now is not the time to let giant ISPs censor what we see and do online.

Censorship by ISPs is a serious problem. Comcast has throttled Netflix, AT&T blocked FaceTime, Time Warner Cable throttled the popular game League of Legends, and Verizon admitted it will introduce fast lanes for sites that pay—and slow lanes for everyone else—if the FCC lifts the rules. This hurts consumers and businesses large and small.

Courts have made clear that if the FCC ends Title II classification, the FCC must let ISPs offer fast lanes to websites for a fee, and Chairman Pai has made clear that he intends to do just this.

But if you let ISPs make some websites fast and others artificially slow—for a fee—you will kill the open marketplace that has enabled millions of small businesses and created the 5 most valuable companies in America—just to further enrich a few much less valuable cable giants famous for sky-high prices and abysmal customer service.

I'm sending this to the FCC's open proceeding, but I worry that Chairman Pai, a former Verizon lawyer, has made his plans and will ignore me and millions of other Americans.

So I'm also sending this to my members of Congress. Please publicly support Title II rules and denounce Chairman Pai's plans. Do whatever you can to dissuade him.

Thank you!
Dr. Alton and the Rev. Mrs Norma Smith

We already pay high rates for data. This attempt by the big telecoms to extort even more revenue by threatening content providers with "pay to play" is an outrage!

I don't want ISPs to have the power to block websites, slow them down, make some more accessible than others, or split the Internet into "fast lanes" for companies that pay and "slow lanes" for the rest.

I support leaving the Net Neutrality rules unchanged for the near term future.  It appears the main driver for change is to give more goodies to large corporations, not keep the internet open to all. I happen to like some large business but I don't think they need even more government support.\nThank you for your time.

As a small business owner who provides jobs in rural McCall Idaho, the planned destruction of "net neutrality" is going to harm my business, my customers, and my employees.

I rely on the internet for connecting with my customers and delivering content to them. If you create "fast lanes" only for those big corporations that have the resources to pay, you will kill my opportunity to reach my customers.

If you kill a free and open internet, you kill JOBS in rural places like mine. We cannot survive as a business here locally - we rely on connecting to a GLOBAL client base and through our efforts, bringing dollars here. Our economy absolutely needs stable businesses like mine, as the local tourist industry fluctuates wildly throughout the year.

My understanding is that the president is PRO BUSINESS.

Well, if you kill net neutrality, you are KILLING BUSINESS and that is the opposite of pro-business.

I hope you will see the absolute folly of making changes that will harm voting small business people like myself in RED states.

Thank you!
Morgan Giddings

In the past ISPs have throttled content based on their own determination of what was lawful or permissible, and had to be forced to stop in the courts. Isn’t it possible they could do this again? I’m also concerned by mobile providers who say a plan is “unlimited,” but when you exceed the data cap, only throttle sites and services that aren’t part of their approved zero-rating network. \nBroadband providers should not be in the driver’s seat, determining how you use the internet, controlling what content you view, or dictating what kind of devices you can use.

It is my understanding that the FCC Chairman intends to reverse net neutrality rules and put big Internet Service Providers in charge of the internet. I am firmly against this action, and believe that these ISPs will operate solely in their own interests and not in the interests of what is best for the American public. In the past 10 years, broadband companies have been guilty of: * deliberately throttling internet traffic * squeezing customers with arbitrary data caps * misleading consumers about the meaning of “unlimited” internet * giving privileged treatment to companies they own * strong-arming cities to prevent them from giving their residents high-speed internet * avoiding real competition at all costs Consumers, small businesses, and all Americans deserve an open internet. So to restate my position: I am against the chairman's plan to reverse the net neutrality rules. I believe doing so will destroy a vital engine for innovation, growth, and communication.

I feel that internet companies are still far too unrestricted but that the focus for restrictions should be on larger ISPs
I feel that the massive ISPs line Comcast, charter, and time-Warner have been given too much freedom for to Long and that they should be broken down to allow room for smaller companies to compete and grow.
As for throttling blocking and internet fast Lanes the answer to any question is "UNDER NO CIRCUMSTANCES SHOULD THESE RULES BE CHANGED OTHER THAN IN THE MORE STRICT DIRECTION"
The internet boom was great but it was also full of problems, it's time to grow up and deal with them

Comcast has throttled Netflix, AT&T blocked FaceTime, Time Warner Cable throttled the popular game League of Legends, and Verizon admitted it will introduce fast lanes for sites that pay—and slow lanes for everyone else—if the FCC lifts the rules. This hurts consumers and businesses large and small.

Courts have made clear that if the FCC ends Title II classification, the FCC must let ISPs offer fast lanes to websites for a fee, and Chairman Pai has made clear that he intends to do just this.

But if you let ISPs make some websites fast and others artificially slow—for a fee—you will kill the open marketplace that has enabled millions of small businesses and created the 5 most valuable companies in America—just to further enrich a few much less valuable cable giants famous for sky-high prices and abysmal customer service.

I'm sending this to the FCC's open proceeding, but I worry that Chairman Pai, a former Verizon lawyer, has made his plans and will ignore me and millions of other Americans.

So I'm also sending this to my members of Congress. Please publicly support Title II rules and denounce Chairman Pai's plans. Do whatever you can to dissuade him.

Thank you!

Justin Pearce

I stand firmly against this proposal. Preserving net neutrality is imperative to the free market. Allowing telecom companies to have it their way would have massive repercussions that would affect everyone, from competitors to consumers - sans, of course, telecom companies and anti-neutrality politicians. Without the Title II rules and regulations, telecom corporations are given unchecked power and control over their customers' Internet access; there would be nothing to stop Comcast, for example, from throttling competitors by placing additional charges on their services or blocking their sites entirely in order to extort money from their customers. The American consumer stands to gain absolutely nothing by supporting this proposal. It is anti-neutrality, anti-free market, and anti-consumer. It does not promote the rights of consumers, it gives telecom companies to ability to unfairly crush competition whilst shafting their customers in the process. As such, I strongly disapprove of this proposal, and urge the FCC to reconsider its priorities in promoting corporate interests as opposed to those of its constituents.

The FCC Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me. I urge you to protect them.

I don't want ISPs to have the power to block websites, slow them down, make some more accessible than others, or split the Internet into "fast lanes" for companies that pay and "slow lanes" for the rest.

Now is not the time to let giant ISPs censor what we see and do online.

Censorship by ISPs is a serious problem. Comcast has throttled Netflix, AT&T blocked FaceTime, Time Warner Cable throttled the popular game League of Legends, and Verizon admitted it will introduce fast lanes for sites that pay—and slow lanes for everyone else—if the FCC lifts the rules. This hurts consumers and businesses large and small.

Courts have made clear that if the FCC ends Title II classification, the FCC must let ISPs offer fast lanes to websites for a fee, and Chairman Pai has made clear that he intends to do just this.

But if you let ISPs make some websites fast and others artificially slow—for a fee—you will kill the open marketplace that has enabled millions of small businesses and created the 5 most valuable companies in America—just to further enrich a few much less valuable cable giants famous for sky-high prices and abysmal customer service.

I'm sending this to the FCC's open proceeding, but I worry that Chairman Pai, a former Verizon lawyer, has made his plans and will ignore me and millions of other Americans.

So I'm also sending this to my members of Congress. Please publicly support Title II rules and denounce Chairman Pai's plans. Do whatever you can to dissuade him.

Thank you!
BRYAN

I feel strongly about maintaining net neutrality. Creating additional barriers to entry for small web-based firms will have a negative impact on the economy.  Here is an excerpt from my economics textbook: "The existence of barriers to entry make the market less contestable and less competitive. The greater the barriers to entry which exist, the less competitive the market will be. Barriers to entry are an essential aspect of monopoly markets." 

The role of government is to level the playing field, strengthen competition and intervene when the market fails. Rolling back net neutrality is clearly not the purview of government.

As a consumer I feel strongly about being able to access all content at the same speed. Weakening net neutrality will decrease my choices and bias my decisions.

Thank you for reading my comment.

As a small business owner who provides jobs in rural McCall Idaho, the planned destruction of "net neutrality" is going to harm my business, my customers, and my employees.

I rely on the internet for connecting with my customers and delivering content to them. If you create "fast lanes" only for those big corporations that have the resources to pay, you will kill my opportunity to reach my customers.

If you kill a free and open internet, you kill JOBS in rural places like mine. We cannot survive as a business here locally - we rely on connecting to a GLOBAL client base and through our efforts, bringing dollars here. Our economy absolutely needs stable businesses like mine, as the local tourist industry fluctuates wildly throughout the year.

My understanding is that the president is PRO BUSINESS.

Well, if you kill net neutrality, you are KILLING BUSINESS and that is the opposite of pro-business.

I hope you will see the absolute folly of making changes that will harm voting small business people like myself in RED states.

Thank you!
Morgan Giddings

Citizens need protection from internet providers!

Regarding "net neutrality", I only have one choice for internet service, which means that I am at the mercy of my internet provider.  If I pay for access to the internet, I don't want my provider deciding who I can have access to, or deciding how fast or slow certain websites will be allowed to download - I pay for access, and my provider should not be able to monitor or limit who I access.  This is a free speech issue.

Nor do I want my internet provider monitoring my internet usage and selling that information without my EXPLICIT consent.  Already the government is too slow in protecting citizens from corporations selling our personal information, so we can't keep giving up our personal freedoms to corporations.

Based on all of that, internet providers should be regulated like a utility, especially in this day and age where our society can't function without an internet that is open to all.  Corporations deciding what I can or can't watch is a slippery slope that Americans should not have to be concerned about - but it appears that we have to based on what the FCC is planning to do in the name of "corporate needs", not "citizen needs".

Let's keep net neutrality the way it is now.  Efforts to throttle service to individuals and by smaller players in the market are anticompetitive and will adversely affect the ability of individuals to access and use critical infrastructure.

Now is not the time to let giant ISPs censor what we see and do online.

Censorship by ISPs is a serious problem. Comcast has throttled Netflix, AT&T blocked FaceTime, Time Warner Cable throttled the popular game League of Legends, and Verizon admitted it will introduce fast lanes for sites that pay—and slow lanes for everyone else—if the FCC lifts the rules. This hurts consumers and businesses large and small.

Courts have made clear that if the FCC ends Title II classification, the FCC must let ISPs offer fast lanes to websites for a fee, and Chairman Pai has made clear that he intends to do just this.

But if you let ISPs make some websites fast and others artificially slow—for a fee—you will kill the open marketplace that has enabled millions of small businesses and created the 5 most valuable companies in America—just to further enrich a few much less valuable cable giants famous for sky-high prices and abysmal customer service.

I'm sending this to the FCC's open proceeding, but I worry that Chairman Pai, a former Verizon lawyer, has made his plans and will ignore me and millions of other Americans.

So I'm also sending this to my members of Congress. Please publicly support Title II rules and denounce Chairman Pai's plans. Do whatever you can to dissuade him.

Thank you!
Gloria Constantin

It is my intent to inform the FCC that I am firmly and vehemently against removing Net Neutrality rules. Internet Service Providers (ISP's) should not be given the ability to choose how and what to stream through their services. As a customer I pay for access to the internet period. The ISP should have no say in how I use the service I am paying for, nor should they be allowed to throttle, deny, or in any way interfere with my choices of where to go or what to do when using the internet. By removing Net Neutrality you are effectively letting ISP's control the internet and choose who will thrive and who will not. To give an analogy, allowing ISP's to"voluntarily agree" to Net Neutrality is akin to allowing a fox to "voluntarily agree" not to eat the hens while guarding the hen house. ISP's have proven time and again that they do not care about customers, customer choice, and innovation. This has been demonstrated by ISP's colluding to avoid competing with each other, arbitrary data caps, providing misleading (if not outright lying)\nadvertising, charging nonsensical fee's that are only added to pad their bottom line, and let's not forget Comcast throttling Netfilx which started this whole thing . Simply put, placing and organization (ISP's) in charge of enforcing rules that they have a vested and conflicting interest is bad for consumers, bad for innovation, and bad\npolicy. There has been no evidence that Net Neutrality has harmed anyone. However, the argument that removing Net Neutrality will give people more choice will result in the exact opposite to be true as the only choices people have will be whatever the ISP will allow. Loss of Net Neutrality will be a loss of democracy and freedom of speech

Sally Vering

Dear Chairman Pai \n\nThank you for your efforts to repeal the federal government’s Title II internet regulations. I support removing these regulations so that the internet is once again free and open. Repealing Title II will increase broadband deployment and competition, and expand consumer choice.

The FCC Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me. I urge you to protect them.

I don't want ISPs to have the power to block websites, slow them down, make some more accessible than others, or split the Internet into "fast lanes" for companies that pay and "slow lanes" for the rest.

Now is not the time to let giant ISPs censor what we see and do online.

Thank you!

The FCC Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me. I urge you to protect them.

I don't want ISPs to have the power to block websites, slow them down, make some more accessible than others, or split the Internet into "fast lanes" for companies that pay and "slow lanes" for the rest.

Now is not the time to let giant ISPs censor what we see and do online.

Censorship by ISPs is a serious problem. Comcast has throttled Netflix, AT&T blocked FaceTime, Time Warner Cable throttled the popular game League of Legends, and Verizon admitted it will introduce fast lanes for sites that pay—and slow lanes for everyone else—if the FCC lifts the rules. This hurts consumers and businesses large and small.

Courts have made clear that if the FCC ends Title II classification, the FCC must let ISPs offer fast lanes to websites for a fee, and Chairman Pai has made clear that he intends to do just this.

But if you let ISPs make some websites fast and others artificially slow—for a fee—you will kill the open marketplace that has enabled millions of small businesses and created the 5 most valuable companies in America—just to further enrich a few much less valuable cable giants famous for sky-high prices and abysmal customer service.

I'm sending this to the FCC's open proceeding, but I worry that Chairman Pai, a former Verizon lawyer, has made his plans and will ignore me and millions of other Americans.

So I'm also sending this to my members of Congress. Please publicly support Title II rules and denounce Chairman Pai's plans. Do whatever you can to dissuade him.

Thank you!
Barbara Rombold-Gillies
Please do NOT roll back net neutrality rules. Do not play favorites with Internet traffic!

It is my understanding that the FCC Chairman intends to reverse net neutrality rules and put big Internet Service Providers in charge of the internet. I am firmly against this action, and believe that these ISPs will operate solely in their own interests and not in the interests of what is best for the American public. In the past 10 years, broadband companies have been guilty of: * deliberately throttling internet traffic * squeezing customers with arbitrary data caps * misleading consumers about the meaning of “unlimited” internet * giving privileged treatment to companies they own * strong-arming cities to prevent them from giving their residents high-speed internet * avoiding real competition at all costs Consumers, small businesses, and all Americans deserve an open internet. So to restate my position: I am against the chairman's plan to reverse the net neutrality rules. I believe doing so will destroy a vital engine for innovation, growth, and communication.

So I'm also sending this to my members of Congress. Please publicly support Title II rules and denounce Chairman Pai's plans. Do whatever you can to dissuade him.

Thank you!
Joseph Friesen

The FCC Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me. I urge you to protect them.

I don't want ISPs to have the power to block websites, slow them down, make some more accessible than others, or split the Internet into "fast lanes" for companies that pay and "slow lanes" for the rest.

Now is not the time to let giant ISPs censor what we see and do online.

Censorship by ISPs is a serious problem. Comcast has throttled Netflix, AT&T blocked FaceTime, Time Warner Cable throttled the popular game League of Legends, and Verizon admitted it will introduce fast lanes for sites that pay—and slow lanes for everyone else—if the FCC lifts the rules. This hurts consumers and businesses large and small.

Courts have made clear that if the FCC ends Title II classification, the FCC must let ISPs offer fast lanes to websites for a fee, and Chairman Pai has made clear that he intends to do just this.

But if you let ISPs make some websites fast and others artificially slow—for a fee—you will kill the open marketplace that has enabled millions of small businesses and created the 5 most valuable companies in America—just to further enrich a few much less valuable cable giants famous for sky-high prices and abysmal customer service.

Thank you!

Now is not the time to let giant ISPs censor what we see and do online.

Censorship by ISPs is a serious problem. Comcast has throttled Netflix, AT&T blocked FaceTime, Time Warner Cable throttled the popular game League of Legends, and Verizon admitted it will introduce fast lanes for sites that pay—and slow lanes for everyone else—if the FCC lifts the rules. This hurts consumers and businesses large and small.

Courts have made clear that if the FCC ends Title II classification, the FCC must let ISPs offer fast lanes to websites for a fee, and Chairman Pai has made clear that he intends to do just this.

But if you let ISPs make some websites fast and others artificially slow—for a fee—you will kill the open marketplace that has enabled millions of small businesses and created the 5 most valuable companies in America—just to further enrich a few much less valuable cable giants famous for sky-high prices and abysmal customer service.

I'm sending this to the FCC's open proceeding, but I worry that Chairman Pai, a former Verizon lawyer, has made his plans and will ignore me and millions of other Americans.

So I'm also sending this to my members of Congress. Please publicly support Title II rules and denounce Chairman Pai's plans. Do whatever you can to dissuade him.

Thank you!
Stephanie Cardwell

This hurts consumers and businesses large and small.

Courts have made clear that if the FCC ends Title II classification, the FCC must let ISPs offer fast lanes to websites for a fee, and Chairman Pai has made clear that he intends to do just this.

But if you let ISPs make some websites fast and others artificially slow—for a fee—you will kill the open marketplace that has enabled millions of small businesses and created the 5 most valuable companies in America—just to further enrich a few much less valuable cable giants famous for sky-high prices and abysmal customer service.

I'm sending this to the FCC's open proceeding, but I worry that Chairman Pai, a former Verizon lawyer, has made his plans and will ignore me and millions of other Americans.

So I'm also sending this to my members of Congress. Please publicly support Title II rules and denounce Chairman Pai's plans. Do whatever you can to dissuade him.

Thank you!
Christine Love

The FCC Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me. 

1.  I urge you to keep rules that prevent telephone/Cable TV/giant ISP companies from receiving data of Internet users that control how much of what Internet users can and cannot access when.

2.  I don't want ISPs to have the power to block websites, slow them down, make some more accessible than others, or split the Internet into "fast lanes" for companies that pay and "slow lanes" for the rest.

Now is not the time to let giant ISPs censor what we see and do online.

3.  Censorship by ISPs is a serious problem. For example, Comcast has throttled Netflix; AT&T blocked FaceTime; Time Warner Cable throttled the popular game League of Legends; and Verizon admitted it will introduce fast lanes for sites that pay—and slow lanes for everyone else—if the FCC lifts the rules. Courts have made clear that if the FCC ends Title II classification, the FCC must let ISPs offer fast lanes to websites for a fee, and Chairman Pai has made clear that he intends to do just this.

I have been studying the field of computer science for the past 3 years and have programmed for half of my life. I can tell you without a doubt that eliminating net neutrality or "Restoring internet freedom" as you have put it, will without a doubt harm everyone outside of internet providers. Internet providers who I shouldn't need to remind you typically have a monopoly in their area of service and harm consumers and firms alike with little repercussions.\nI say these things assuming you actually care about this. Even if you fail to care about the people who you are supposed to protect, you should know that issues like this are further permeating the collective consciousness and are unlikely to be treated with the degree of passivity that they have been thus far. Even if current events may bolster your willingness to strip us of protections, It should be noted that after your service on the FCC, you will still have careers, and where others have sought to take rights away from the people when new opportunities have shown themselves, ie: the recent broadband privacy bill, retaliations seem to be increasing.. fitting. [See here --> ] https://www.theverge.com/2017/5/4/15545266/congress-privacy-vote-isp-billboards

The FCC Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me. I urge you to protect them.

I don't want ISPs to have the power to block websites, slow them down, make some more accessible than others, or split the Internet into "fast lanes" for companies that pay and "slow lanes" for the rest.

Now is not the time to let giant ISPs censor what we see and do online.

Censorship by ISPs is a serious problem. Comcast has throttled Netflix, AT&T blocked FaceTime, Time Warner Cable throttled the popular game League of Legends, and Verizon admitted it will introduce fast lanes for sites that pay—and slow lanes for everyone else—if the FCC lifts the rules. This hurts consumers and businesses large and small.

Courts have made clear that if the FCC ends Title II classification, the FCC must let ISPs offer fast lanes to websites for a fee, and Chairman Pai has made clear that he intends to do just this.

But if you let ISPs make some websites fast and others artificially slow—for a fee—you will kill the open marketplace that has enabled millions of small businesses and created the 5 most valuable companies in America—just to further enrich a few much less valuable cable giants famous for sky-high prices and abysmal customer service.

I'm sending this to the FCC's open proceeding, but I worry that Chairman Pai, a former Verizon lawyer, has made his plans and will ignore me and millions of other Americans.

So I'm also sending this to my members of Congress. Please publicly support Title II rules and denounce Chairman Pai's plans. Do whatever you can to dissuade him.

Thank you!
Christian

So I'm also sending this to my members of Congress. Please publicly support Title II rules and denounce Chairman Pai's plans. Do whatever you can to dissuade him.

Thank you!
Clare Abreu

The FCC Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me. I urge you to protect them.

I don't want ISPs to have the power to block websites, slow them down, make some more accessible than others, or split the Internet into "fast lanes" for companies that pay and "slow lanes" for the rest.

Now is not the time to let giant ISPs censor what we see and do online.

Censorship by ISPs is a serious problem. Comcast has throttled Netflix, AT&T blocked FaceTime, Time Warner Cable throttled the popular game League of Legends, and Verizon admitted it will introduce fast lanes for sites that pay—and slow lanes for everyone else—if the FCC lifts the rules. This hurts consumers and businesses large and small.

Courts have made clear that if the FCC ends Title II classification, the FCC must let ISPs offer fast lanes to websites for a fee, and Chairman Pai has made clear that he intends to do just this.

But if you let ISPs make some websites fast and others artificially slow—for a fee—you will kill the open marketplace that has enabled millions of small businesses and created the 5 most valuable companies in America—just to further enrich a few much less valuable cable giants famous for sky-high prices and abysmal customer service.

I'm sending this to the FCC's open proceeding, but I worry that Chairman Pai, a former Verizon lawyer, has made his plans and will ignore me and millions of other Americans.

Thank you!

I don't want ISPs to have the power to block websites, slow them down, make some more accessible than others, or split the Internet into "fast lanes" for companies that pay and "slow lanes" for the rest.

Now is not the time to let giant ISPs censor what we see and do online.

Censorship by ISPs is a serious problem. Comcast has throttled Netflix, AT&T blocked FaceTime, Time Warner Cable throttled the popular game League of Legends, and Verizon admitted it will introduce fast lanes for sites that pay—and slow lanes for everyone else—if the FCC lifts the rules. This hurts consumers and businesses large and small.

Courts have made clear that if the FCC ends Title II classification, the FCC must let ISPs offer fast lanes to websites for a fee, and Chairman Pai has made clear that he intends to do just this.

But if you let ISPs make some websites fast and others artificially slow—for a fee—you will kill the open marketplace that has enabled millions of small businesses and created the 5 most valuable companies in America—just to further enrich a few much less valuable cable giants famous for sky-high prices and abysmal customer service.

I'm sending this to the FCC's open proceeding, but I worry that Chairman Pai, a former Verizon lawyer, has made his plans and will ignore me and millions of other Americans.

So I'm also sending this to my members of Congress. Please publicly support Title II rules and denounce Chairman Pai's plans. Do whatever you can to dissuade him.

Thank you!
Robert Hanno

Consideration of the elimination of “bright lines” is without merit. It is argued this will
facilitate in the management of internet traffic. But, revoking the rights associated with net neutrality
places consumers at an undue disadvantage. When considering “internet management” in the context of
internetworking, “internet management” is unwarranted.
One has to wonder, why manage a series of moves an individual may make at any time for any
reason, who would be managing, and who would be managed? If “bright lines” are eliminated, these
issues will not be addressed. For an untold number of people, using the internet will be a baseless
inculcation and many will endure unwarranted difficulty. The ability, not the right, of internet service providers to imbue the experience under the premise of management will leave most consumers defenseless.
We will be better off if net neutrality is left alone. Any attempt to use the internet as means for
economic prospect must go forward under the premise of building on what we have, not undoing it.

The proposed changes benefit no one but the current providers. They run counter to every notion of public service, as does every lie and half-truth used in their defense. From the Tea Party to the DSA, every American of every ideology and persuasion needs an open Internet.

But if you let ISPs make some websites fast and others artificially slow—for a fee—you will kill the open marketplace that has enabled millions of small businesses and created the 5 most valuable companies in America—just to further enrich a few much less valuable cable giants famous for sky-high prices and abysmal customer service.

I'm sending this to the FCC's open proceeding, but I worry that Chairman Pai, a former Verizon lawyer, has made his plans and will ignore me and millions of other Americans.

So I'm also sending this to my members of Congress. Please publicly support Title II rules and denounce Chairman Pai's plans. Do whatever you can to dissuade him.

Thank you!
Zakaria

The FCC Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me. I urge you to protect them.

I don't want ISPs to have the power to block websites, slow them down, make some more accessible than others, or split the Internet into "fast lanes" for companies that pay and "slow lanes" for the rest.

I think the fact that the proposal to remove Net Neutrality is being called "The Restore Internet Freedom Act" tells us everything we need to know. Anyone familiar with current Orwellian practice of naming unpopular bill's for the opposite of that bill's intended effects can see from a mile away that this bill is intended to revoke Internet Freedom. Other comments have expertly detailed the litany abuses consumers have suffered at the hands of the monopolistic Internet Service Providers. I would like to point out that America has the worst broadband access in the developed world precisely because the ISP's function as an oligopoly. This will only make the USA less competitive. All to fulfill the wishes of a few massive and predatory conglomerates. \n\nYou ought to be ashamed of yourselves for even considering this course of action.

But if you let ISPs make some websites fast and others artificially slow—for a fee—you will kill the open marketplace that has enabled millions of small businesses and created the 5 most valuable companies in America—just to further enrich a few much less valuable cable giants famous for sky-high prices and abysmal customer service.

I'm sending this to the FCC's open proceeding, but I worry that Chairman Pai, a former Verizon lawyer, has made his plans and will ignore me and millions of other Americans.

So I'm also sending this to my members of Congress. Please publicly support Title II rules and denounce Chairman Pai's plans. Do whatever you can to dissuade him.

Thank you!
James

The FCC Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me. I urge you to protect them.

I don't want ISPs to have the power to block websites, slow them down, make some more accessible than others, or split the Internet into "fast lanes" for companies that pay and "slow lanes" for the rest.

Now is not the time to let giant ISPs censor what we see and do online.

Censorship by ISPs is a serious problem. Comcast has throttled Netflix, AT&T blocked FaceTime, Time Warner Cable throttled the popular game League of Legends, and Verizon admitted it will introduce fast lanes for sites that pay—and slow lanes for everyone else—if the FCC lifts the rules. Dear FCC,

removing net neutrality is allowing corporations to tell the American people what to think, who to know, what to buy, and what to be. 1984 is not specific to socialism, it will absolutely happen if we allow corporations access to our personal information (which we have done) AND then let them censor what we see. Removing net neutrality is a threat to the constitution because it allows corporations (WHO ARE NOT PEOPLE) to choose the government and its subsequent policies by only allowing the voters to see what they want them to see.

It is profoundly unethical that Ajit Pai is doing this to help out his corporate buddies. As the leader of the FCC, he ought to be the person who protects the PEOPLE from the corporations. And yet, he is selling us out for a kickback. Oppose him. What he is doing is categorically wrong and he knows this, he just doesn't seem to care. But we need you to care. Please, protect net neutrality.

Comcast has throttled Netflix, AT&T blocked FaceTime, Time Warner Cable throttled the popular game League of Legends, and Verizon admitted it will introduce fast lanes for sites that pay—and slow lanes for everyone else—if the FCC lifts the rules. This hurts consumers and businesses large and small.

Courts have made clear that if the FCC ends Title II classification, the FCC must let ISPs offer fast lanes to websites for a fee, and Chairman Pai has made clear that he intends to do just this.

But if you let ISPs make some websites fast and others artificially slow—for a fee—you will kill the open marketplace that has enabled millions of small businesses and created the 5 most valuable companies in America—just to further enrich a few much less valuable cable giants famous for sky-high prices and abysmal customer service.

I'm sending this to the FCC's open proceeding, but I worry that Chairman Pai, a former Verizon lawyer, has made his plans and will ignore me and millions of other Americans.

So I'm also sending this to my members of Congress. Please publicly support Title II rules and denounce Chairman Pai's plans. Do whatever you can to dissuade him.

Thank you!
Jonah Aitchison

Dear FCC Commissioners:     Please do not repeal the net neutrality rule.  I want net neutrality to continue because it facilitates my access to diversity of internet sites and information, protects my privacy, protects my record of internet usage, and gives me more control over who knows about my internet searches and web site visits.   Retain net neutrality, and don't swallow the specious argument that net neutrality is slowing the deployment of high-speed internet by cable companies and other carriers.    Please protect individual citizens by retaining net neutrality!  Frank Heintz

The FCC Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me. I urge you to protect them.

  Most Americans only have one choice for true high speed Internet access: our local cable company. Cable companies (and wireless carriers) are actively lobbying Congress and the FCC for the power to:

  * Block sites and apps, to charge them "access fees"
  * Slow sites and apps to a crawl, to establish paid "fast lanes" (normal speed) and slow lanes (artificially low speeds)
  * Impose arbitrarily low data caps, so they can charge sites to escape those caps, or privilege their own services ("zero rating")

  They're doing it so they can use their monopoly power to stand between me and the sites I want to access, extorting money from us both. I'll be forced to pay more to access the sites I want, and sites will have to pay a kind of protection money to every major cable company or wireless carrier—just to continue working properly! The FCC's Open Internet Rules are the only thing standing in their way.

  I'm sending this to letter to my two senators, my representative, the White House, and the FCC. First, to the FCC: don’t interfere with my ability to access what I want on the Internet, or with websites' ability to reach me. You should leave the existing rules in place, and enforce them.

  To my senators: you have the power to stop FCC Chair Ajit Pai from abusing the rules by refusing to vote for his reconfirmation. I expect you to use that power. Pai, a former Verizon employee, has made it clear he intends to gut the rules to please his former employer and other major carriers, despite overwhelming support for the rules from voters in both parties. I urge you publicly oppose Pai's confirmation on these grounds.

  To the White House: Ajit Pai, a former Verizon employee, is acting in the interests of his former employer, not the American people. America deserves better. Appoint an FCC Chair who will protect the economic miracle that is the Internet from media monopolies like AT&T, Time Warner Cable, and Comcast/NBC/Universal.

  To my representative: please publicly oppose Ajit Pai's plan to oppose the rules, and do everything you can to persuade the Senate and the White House to oppose Pai's nomination. 

  I would be happy to speak more with anyone on your staff about the rules and why they’re so important to me. Please notify me of any opportunities to meet with you or your staff.
Allison Sanbongi

The FCC Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me. I urge you to protect them.

I don't want ISPs to have the power to block websites, slow them down, make some more accessible than others, or split the Internet into "fast lanes" for companies that pay and "slow lanes" for the rest.

Now is not the time to let giant ISPs censor what we see and do online.

Censorship by ISPs is a serious problem. Comcast has throttled Netflix, AT&T blocked FaceTime, Time Warner Cable throttled the popular game League of Legends, and Verizon admitted it will introduce fast lanes for sites that pay—and slow lanes for everyone else—if the FCC lifts the rules. This hurts consumers and businesses large and small.

Courts have made clear that if the FCC ends Title II classification, the FCC must let ISPs offer fast lanes to websites for a fee, and Chairman Pai has made clear that he intends to do just this.

But if you let ISPs make some websites fast and others artificially slow—for a fee—you will kill the open marketplace that has enabled millions of small businesses and created the 5 most valuable companies in America—just to further enrich a few much less valuable cable giants famous for sky-high prices and abysmal customer service.

I'm sending this to the FCC's open proceeding, but I worry that Chairman Pai, a former Verizon lawyer, has made his plans and will ignore me and millions of other Americans.

So I'm also sending this to my members of Congress. Please publicly support Title II rules and denounce Chairman Pai's plans. Do whatever you can to dissuade him.

Thank you!
Michael Lubker

Comcast has throttled Netflix, AT&T blocked FaceTime, Time Warner Cable throttled the popular game League of Legends, and Verizon admitted it will introduce fast lanes for sites that pay—and slow lanes for everyone else—if the FCC lifts the rules. This hurts consumers and businesses large and small.

Courts have made clear that if the FCC ends Title II classification, the FCC must let ISPs offer fast lanes to websites for a fee, and Chairman Pai has made clear that he intends to do just this.

But if you let ISPs make some websites fast and others artificially slow—for a fee—you will kill the open marketplace that has enabled millions of small businesses and created the 5 most valuable companies in America—just to further enrich a few much less valuable cable giants famous for sky-high prices and abysmal customer service.

I'm sending this to the FCC's open proceeding, but I worry that Chairman Pai, a former Verizon lawyer, has made his plans and will ignore me and millions of other Americans.

So I'm also sending this to my members of Congress. Please publicly support Title II rules and denounce Chairman Pai's plans. Do whatever you can to dissuade him.

Thank you!
Derek Heiberger

Paragraph 82 asks for input on whether throttling should be regulated. In the past ISPs have throttled content based on their own determination of what was lawful or permissible, and had to be forced to stop in the courts. Isn’t it possible they could do this again? I’m also concerned by mobile providers who say a plan is “unlimited,” but when you exceed the data cap, only throttle sites and services that aren’t part of their approved zero-rating network. Thanks for reading my comment.

Dear FCC,

Real Net Neutrality, not the multi-tiered system Big Telecom is lobbying for, is essential to maintaining an open, democratic and free society via the unmitigated exchange of information. Real Net Neutrality is also the backbone of smaller, entrepreneurial businesses that rely on access to the same level of bandwidth as those who they are competing with. Without that level playing field, start-ups, small businesses, non-profits and public service organizations will be stifled and unable to compete. That's just flat out wrong and incompatible with the values and functioning of a democratic, free society.

It is bad enough that Chairman Pai, a former industry lobbyist for Big Telecom, is in any position to decide this issue. He should really recuse yourself from this entire decision-making process. Barring that, the FCC must give the people, not the pay-to-play, Big Telecom interests, the final say in this matter.

That's how democracy and a free society functions.
Philip Johnston

Courts have made clear that if the FCC ends Title II classification, the FCC must let ISPs offer fast lanes to websites for a fee, and Chairman Pai has made clear that he intends to do just this.

But if you let ISPs make some websites fast and others artificially slow—for a fee—you will kill the open marketplace that has enabled millions of small businesses and created the 5 most valuable companies in America—just to further enrich a few much less valuable cable giants famous for sky-high prices and abysmal customer service.

I'm sending this to the FCC's open proceeding, but I worry that Chairman Pai, a former Verizon lawyer, has made his plans and will ignore me and millions of other Americans.

So I'm also sending this to my members of Congress. Please publicly support Title II rules and denounce Chairman Pai's plans. Do whatever you can to dissuade him.

Thank you!
James

dallas holmes

I stand firmly against this proposal. Preserving net neutrality is imperative to the free market. Allowing telecom companies to have it their way would have massive repercussions that would affect everyone, from competitors to consumers - sans, of course, telecom companies and anti-neutrality politicians. Without the Title II rules and regulations, telecom corporations are given unchecked power and control over their customers' Internet access; there would be nothing to stop Comcast, for example, from throttling competitors by placing additional charges on their services or blocking their sites entirely in order to extort money from their customers. The American consumer stands to gain absolutely nothing by supporting this proposal. It is anti-neutrality, anti-free market, and anti-consumer. It does not promote the rights of consumers, it gives telecom companies to ability to unfairly crush competition whilst shafting their customers in the process. As such, I strongly disapprove of this proposal, and urge the FCC to reconsider its priorities in promoting corporate interests as opposed to those of its constituents.

Dear FCC,

Please don't kill the internet
Chance
